title: Holdout Metric Correction for Self-Referential Diseases
key_finding: Excluding 100% self-referential diseases from holdout reveals significantly higher true discovery rates: MEDIUM 40.5% (not 37.6%), HIGH 59.4% (not 54.6%). Self-referential diseases drag down all tier metrics by 3-5pp.
interpretation: Self-referential diseases contribute 0-23% precision to each tier, dragging down averages
MEDIUM tier 'true discovery rate' for non-self-ref diseases is 40.5%, not 37.6% (+2.9pp)
HIGH tier discovery rate is 59.4% for non-self-ref diseases (+4.8pp)
LOW tier: 17.2% vs 13.7% — self-ref diseases inflate LOW count by ~29% with minimal hits
For <50% self-ref (most reliable): MEDIUM = 44.0%, HIGH = 60.8% — much higher true quality
Tier ordering is preserved in all segments: GOLDEN > HIGH > MEDIUM > LOW > FILTER
Self-ref predictions at FILTER still have 4.4% precision — not zero but minimal
The MEDIUM 40% target (from h561) is actually ACHIEVED for non-self-ref diseases (40.5%!)
actionable_implications: Report non-self-ref precision as the 'discovery potential' metric
The system is BETTER than previously thought for discoverable diseases
No code changes needed — this is a reporting/interpretation correction
Could add non_selfref_precision to deliverable metadata for transparency
